DOC.HEAD: Nations Urge Support for New Government, End to Retribution
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE relief efforts, former king saying government won't last; no pickup
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League on Wednesday urged Romania's new government to prevent attacks on Arabs following reports that Arab mercenaries fought for its executed dictator. Britain cautioned Romanian reformers to refrain from revenge attacks. Civic Forum, the Czechoslovak opposition group, said Wednesday the Czechoslovak consulate in Bucharest had confirmed reports of 2,000 foreign mercenaries fighting with those loyal to executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. ``They were positive about Libyans and indicated Syrians and Palestinians'' were involved, Civic Forum spokesman Michael Zantovsky said in Prague after returning from Bucharest. He added that the number of mercenaries could be even higher. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev spoke by telephone with Ion Iliescu, the new interim president, who thanked his old college chum for his support. For the first time, Israel criticized Ceausescu, who had been highly regarded for his support of the Jewish state in the face of East bloc opposition. Romania's former King Michael, who said he would be willing to return, said the new government may collapse. Emergency aid poured into the country and relief agencies said they needed money and blood rather than more food, clothing and other supplies. The list of nations recognizing the new government grew longer. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar promised all possible humanitarian asssistance to Romania and said he hoped the transition to democracy would be peaceful. Some countries, including Czecholsovakia and Norway, the first nation to recognize the new government, arranged for diplomats to travel to Romania. The provisional government, called the National Salvation Committee, took power after Ceausescu's ouster Friday, saying it will hold power until elections can be held in April. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed by a firing squad Monday, the government said. President Bush said he was ``amazed'' at the changes that have taken place in Romania. ``We did say we were concerned that the trial of Ceausescu should have been more open, but that's their matter,'' he said, adding that army seemed to be bringing the remaining pro-Ceausescu forces under control. China's Premier Li Peng and President Yang Shangkun on Wednesday sent congratulations to Romania's new leaders and expressed hope for continued friendship between the countries. Ceausescu's government had close ties with Beijing and Ceausescu was one of the few world leaders to praise China's military crackdown of the student democracy movement in June. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher praised ``the extraordinary courage'' of the Romanian people in a warm message of support to Iliescu. But Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said: ``There mustn't be a bloodbath of revenge now.'' Egypt, although expressing support for the new Romania government, criticized the Ceausescus' execution without a public trial. Officials from the 22-member Arab League met with the Romanian ambassador in Tunis, Tunisia, to demand that Romanian officials promise that Arabs living in Romania not be subjected to ``bad treatment,'' a statement said. The Palestine Liberation Organization alleged Tuesday its diplomatic staff and Palestinian students in Romania have been attacked in recent days. Several Eastern European news agencies have accused Palestinians, Libyans and Syrians of fighting alongside security forces loyal to Ceausescu. Libya, Syria and the PLO have denied the reports. In Jerusalem, a statement by Foreign Minister Moshe Arens to Parliament was the first time Israel openly criticized Ceausescu. Referring to the thousands of victims of the anti-Ceausescu rebellion, Arens said, ``Israel condemns the terrible massacres carried out by Ceausescu's security forces.'' Ceausescu was the only East bloc leader to maintain ties with Israel after the 1967 Middle East War, when the others sided with the Arabs. Joining the United States and a score of states recognizing the new Romanian leadership were Denmark, Czechoslovakia, Malaysia and North Korea, whose hard-line Communist government, led by Kim Il Sung, was often compared to Ceausescu's. However, King Michael, who was deposed in 1947 when the Communists took over and now lives in Switzerland, said he did not expect the new government to last. ``The crowds do not accept what's there now, because they (the government) have communist backgrounds. They have come from Ceausescu's party, they worked with him before. So I don't think the people will accept this,'' he said in a BBC television interview broadcast Wednesday night. The king, who said he would return home immediately if he was wanted, called the plan to hold elections in April ``a little premature'' because Romania's political system had been destroyed over the past 40 years. ``So there is actually no political groundwork to have elections so soon,'' he said. Countries and charities sent or pledged millions of dollars, food, tons of medical supplies and equipment and doctors and nurses to help Romanians. Rony Brauman, president of the non-governmental aid agency Doctors Without Borders which has 43 people working in 13 Romanian cities, said in Paris the most pressing need is money. ``The urgent needs of Romania for drugs and medical and surgical material are now covered,'' said Brauman. ``The problem now is forwarding and distributing this aid as it's needed.'' A Red Cross official told relief workers in Prague that blood is the most urgent necessity. A committee has been set up in Bucharest under the auspices of the Red Cross and the United Nations to coordinate assistance arriving in Bucharest, the Red Cross said. In Washington, The American Red Cross urged people to send money, not goods. It said 500 tons of food, clothing, blankets and medical supplies have arrived or are en route. The Red Cross said it has received information that one Hungarian Red Cross volunteer was fatally shot Friday while bringing relief supplies to the western city of Timisoara.
